narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan
narrative.project_title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project titled 'NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants' expects to generate a significant amount of scientific data, including demographic and clinical data (tabular) and MRI-based imaging data. This will encompass structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS data, along with derived imaging measures/features and supporting documentation such as data dictionaries, protocols, and README files. The dataset will include participant-level clinical/demographic tables for 220 participants (110 affected youth and 110 matched healthy controls) and multi-modal MRI imaging data.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected data, including demographic, clinical, and MRI imaging data, will be preserved and shared. The rationale behind this decision is to maximize the utility of the data for future research, facilitate replication studies, and accelerate discoveries in the field by making these valuable resources available to the broader scientific community. This approach aligns with the principles of open science and the NIH's emphasis on enhancing data sharing and reuse.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate the interpretation and reuse of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible:
- Data dictionaries that describe the variables and codes used in the demographic and clinical datasets.
- Study protocols outlining the procedures for collecting MRI and clinical data.
- README files providing an overview of the dataset structure, content, and any specific instructions for use.
- Information on the standardized scan protocols used for MRI data acquisition.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools and software are needed to access or manipulate the shared scientific data. Specifically, for MRI imaging data:
- FSL (FMRIB Software Library) for analysis of structural and functional MRI data.
- AFNI (Analysis of Functional NeuroImages) for processing and analyzing fMRI and 1H fMRS data.
- 3D Slicer for visualizing and analyzing MRI images.
These tools are widely used in the neuroimaging community and can be accessed through their respective websites or repositories.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. The project will adhere to:
- The Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) standard for organizing and describing MRI data.
- The NIH's National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Data Archive (NDA) guidelines for formatting and submitting demographic and clinical data.
- Standardized ontologies and vocabularies, such as those provided by the NIMH or other relevant organizations, will be used to annotate metadata and ensure consistency across datasets.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). The NDA is a repository that supports the sharing and reuse of data related to mental health research, making it an appropriate choice for this study.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: To ensure that the scientific data are findable and identifiable, each dataset will be assigned a persistent unique identifier (e.g., DOI) upon publication in the NDA. Additionally, datasets will be indexed with standardized metadata to facilitate discovery through search tools provided by the NDA.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available to other users no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data will remain available indefinitely, as per the NDA's policies, to support ongoing research and maximize the impact of the project's findings.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: While the project aims to maximize data sharing, factors that may affect subsequent access, distribution, or reuse include the need to protect participant privacy and confidentiality. All data will be deidentified before sharing, but access to certain sensitive information might require additional approval processes through the NDA.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will be controlled through the NDA's access request system. Users will need to register and agree to the NDA's Data Use Certification agreement before accessing the datasets. This ensures that data are used appropriately and in compliance with ethical standards and regulations.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all identifiable information will be removed from the datasets before they are shared. Participants have been consented for broad data sharing under an approved study protocol that includes provisions for protecting their privacy and confidentiality.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the project's Principal Investigator (PI), in collaboration with the institution's research administration office. Regular oversight meetings will be conducted quarterly to review progress, address any challenges in data management and sharing, and ensure that all datasets are properly documented and submitted to the NDA according to the planned timeline. The PI and the research team will work closely with the NDA support staff as needed to resolve any issues related to data submission or access.
